div2.entryFree: alphabetical letter Y * The twenty-eighth letter of the alphabet: called yaA='N. It is one of the letters termed soft, or weak, and is a letter of prolongation and of augmentation. As a numeral it signifies Ten. -A2- Y for yA frequently occurs in the phrase yarasuwla A@ll~`hi, and in yaA^ay~uhaA. ― -b2- Y inserted to give fulness of sound to kesreh, see art. A. ― -b3- Used lilA_inokaAri, see Alf AlAstnkAr in art. A. ― -b4- Y with sheddeh followed by p converts a part. n. into a quasi-inf. n., as AlmaDoruwbiy~apu, “ the being beaten. ” So, by the relative Y, yaA='u Alnisobapi, substs. and even particles are converted into abstract nouns of quality, as Aisomiy~apN and kayofiy~apN. -A3- yaA is the most common of vocative particles, used in calling to him who is near; [like O!]; and to him who is distant; [like Ho there! Holloa!]; and to him who is between near and distant; [like ho! what ho!]; (Ibn-el-Kátib, in the Káfiyeh, cited in TA, art. A^ayaA.) Pronounced with imáleh, see art. A_im~aA. ― -b2- yaAla for yaA A=la, see l. ― -b3- yaAyaA and yaAyaho, see art. A^ayaA.

R. Q. 1 yaA^oyaA^ahu * , inf. n. yaA^oyaA^ahN and yaA^oyaA='N, [respecting the form of which latter see ZaA^oZaA^a,] He made a show of kindness, benignity, or favour to him. (K.) ― -b2- A_in~amaA huwa yaA^oyaA='N [It is only making a show of kindness, &c.: or, perhaps, He is only one who makes a show of kindness, &c,]. (L.) -A2- yaA^oyaA^a biAlqawomi He called the people: (K: so too in the L, and this is the correct meaning: TA:) or he said to the people yaA^~ayaA^~a, in order that they should assemble, or collect together. (K) ― -b2- yaA^oyaA^a biAlA_ibili He called to the camels by the cry A^aYo, (whence the verb is formed by transposition, TA,) to quiet them. (K.)
yaA^oyaA='N * The cry, or crying, of the bird called yuw^oyuw^. (K.) ― -b2- [See also the verb.] ― -b3- See art. A^ayaA.

yuw^oyuw^N *
A certain bird (S, K) of prey, (S,) resembling the [kind of hawk called] baA$aq: (S, K:) it is of the birds called Suquwr, [pl. of SaqorN,] as are also the baAziY and the $aAhiyn and the zur~aq and the baA$aq: (AHát in TA, in art. b$q:) accord. to Dmr, it is a small bird, short-tailed, the temperament of which is, in comparison with that of the bA$q, cold and moist; for it is more patient, or enduring, and heavier in motion: the people of Egypt and Syria, he adds, call it jalamN, on account of the lightness and swiftness of its wings: (TA:) pl. yaA^=y^iYu, and, in a verse, yaA^=y^iYo. (S.) ― -b2- Also, accord. to AA, The head, or uppermost part, of a vessel in which kuHol (collyrium) is kept: mentioned before as called buw^obuw^N, which is perhaps a mistake for yw^yw^. (TA.)

1 yay^isa * , (S, M, A, Msb, K,) mina Al$~aYo'i, (S, A *, Msb,) aor. yayoy^asu and yayoy^isu, (S, M, Msb, K,) the latter of which is extr., (Sb, S, M, K,) like yaHosibu, aor. of Hasiba, and yanoEimu, aor. of naEima, (As, S, TA,) and is of the dial. of the higher classes of Mudar, as are also the similar instances, but the former is of the dial. of the lower classes of the Mudar; (AZ, S, Msb, TA;) or, as Sb says, accord. to his companions, the verb was originally of two forms, yay^isa, aor. yayoy^asu, and yaA^asa, aor. yayoy^isu, and a compound [which is yay^isa having yayoy^isu for its aor.] was then formed from the two; but as to wamiqa, aor. yamiqu, and wafiqa, aor. yafiqu, and warima. aor. yarimu, and waliYa, aor. yaliY, and waviqa, aor. yaviqu, and wariva, aor. yarivu, in each of these only one form is allowable, with the kesr; (S, TA;) and some change the second Y of the aor. of yay^isa into A, and say yaAyasu and yaA='asu; (Mbr, S, TA;) and I'Ab reads, in the Kur. xii. 87, yiyy^asu, after the manner of the dial. of those who pronounce the first letter of the aor. with kesr excepting such as is with Y [for its first letter], (K, TA,) which dial, is that of Temeem and Keys and Hudheyl and Asad; (Ks, Lh, TA;) the case of Y being made an exception by them because kesr with that letter is difficult of pronunciation; (Sb, TA;) but some of the Benoo-Kelb pronounce Y also with kesr, which is extr.; (Fr, Lb, TA:) and this is done in the instances of yiyy^asu and yiyjalu because one Y is here strengthened by another; (K, TA;) [I find also, in a copy of the M, yay^iysu, as an extr. form of the aor. of this verb, on the authority of Sb; but it is doubtless a mistranscription for yiyy^asu; and there is another evident mistranscription in a quotation from Sb immediately following in that copy, relating to aors. of the form of yiyy^asu, which has been rendered correctly above, in the present work, from the TA;] inf. n. yaA^osN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and yaA^asN, (TA,) or yaA=sN, (as in a copy of the M,) and yaA=sapN; (Ibn-'Abbád, M, K, TA [but in a MS. copy of the K I find it written yaA^asapN; and in the CK, yaA^osap;]) and A_iyaAsN is also used as an inf. n. of this verb, though properly an inf. n. of 4; (Msb;) He despaired of the thing; syn. of the inf. n. qunuwT, (S, A, K,) contr. of rajaA='N: (M, A, K:) or he cut off hope of the thing: (A, K: *) or his hope of the thing became cut off: (Mgh:) and ↓ A_isotayoy^asa signifies the same, (S, A, K,) in like manner followed by mano; (S;) and so does ↓ A_it~aA^asa, (S, K,) [originally A_iytaA^asa,] of the measure A_ifotaEala, but with incorporation [of the Y into the t]. (S.) It is allowable to transpose the letters of yay^isa, so as to say A^ayisa; but not those of the inf. n. (Msb.) There is not a word in the Arabic language commencing with Y followed by ' except yay^isa [and its derivatives] (IKtt) [and yaA^ayaA^a and its derivatives, and words commencing with an augmentative Y followed by a radical
yaAu^a ]. The expression laA yaA^osa mino TuwlK. occurring in a description of Mohammad, means that his stature was such as would not make [one] to despair of his height; for he was nearer to tallness than he was to shortness: (K, * TA:) yA^s is here an indeterminate noun governed in
the accus. case by the negative lA: (TA:) or, accord. to one relation, the words are, laA yaAy^isa mino TuwlK, [in the CK, erroneously, lA yAyasu,] meaning, that his height was not despaired of; i. e., he who vied with him in tallness would not despair of him on account of his excessive height: (K, TA:) so that yaAy^is is here in the sense of mayow^uws, like maA='N daAfiqN in the sense of madofuwqN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] yay^isato AlmaroA^ahu The woman was, or became, barren. (Msb.) ― -b3- yay^isa, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor. yayoy^asu and yayoy^isu, (M,) also signifies (tropical:) He knew; syn. Ealima; (S, M, A, Msb, K;) in the dial. of En-Nakha'; (S, Msb;) or, accord. to El-Kelbee, (M,) or Ibn-El-Kelbee, (TA,) in the dial. of Wahbeel, a tribe of En-Nakha'; or, accord. to El-Kásim Ibn-Maan, of the dial. of Hawázin. (M, TA.) So in the Kur. [xiii. 30] A^afalamo yayoy^asi A@l~a*iyna A=manuwA [Do not then those who have believed know?]: (S, M, Msb, K:) or, accord. to some of the lexicologists, do not then those who have believed know with a knowledge wherewith they despair of its being otherwise than what they know? or the meaning is, do not then those who have believed despair of the belief of those whom God has described as those who will not believe? (M, TA;) but I' Ab (M, TA) and 'Alee and others (TA) used to read A^afalamo yatabay~ani A@l~a*iyna A=manuwA; and I'Ab said that he thought that the writer had written yayoy^as in a state of drowsiness. (M *, TA.) Soheym Ibn-Wetheel El-Yarboo'ee also uses the verb in this sense, in a verse cited in art. ysr, voce yasara, q. v. (S, M *). [Z-says,] You say, qado yay^isotu A^an~aka rajulu SidoqK, meaning, (tropical:) I have known [that thou art a good man], because with eager desire is restlessness, and with the cessation thereof is quiet and tranquility; wherefore it is said, AlyaA^osu A^aHadu Alr~aAHatayoni [Despair is one of the two states of rest.] (A, TA.)

4 A^ayoA^asahu * , (S, M, A, Mgh, K,) inf. n. A_iyaAsN, (L, Mgh, Msb,) of the same measure as kitaAbN, (Msb,) originally A_iyoA=sN, (L, Msb,) like A_iyoEaAsN, (L,) and A_iyomaAnN, (Msb,) He made him to despair: (S, M, A, K:) or to cut off hope: (A:) or to cease to have hope: (Mgh:) mano ka*aA of such a thing: (S:) as also ↓ A=yasahu [from A^ayisa]. (Mgh, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A^ayoA^usahaA A@ll~`hu God made her to be, or become, barren. (Msb.)
8 A_iyotaAa^a see 1.
10 A_isotayoAa^a see 1.

yaA^asN *
Phthisis, or consumption; syn. sil~N; (M, K;) because he who is affected by it is despaired of; (M;) or [because] the first who was affected by it was AlyaA^asu, (K, TA,) or A_iloyaAs, (TA,) the son of Mudar the son of Nizár: (K, TA:) or, as Suh says, in the R, this disease was called daA='u yaAs, or daA='u A_iloyaAsa, because AlyAs the son of Mudar died of it. (TA.)
yaw^usN * : see yaAy^isN.
yaw^uwsN * : see yaAy^isN.
yay^iysN * : see yaAy^isN.

yaAy^isN * (M, Mgh, Msb) and ↓ yay^iys (M) and ↓ yaw^uwsN (S, M, A, K) and ↓ yaw^usN (M, K) Despairing: (S, M, A, Mgh, K:) but the third has an intensive signification, (Bd, xli. 49,) [and so the last.]
yaAy^isapN * , A barren woman. (Msb.)

mayow^uwsN minohu *
Despaired of. (M, Mgh, Msb. *)
2 xar~abuwhu wyab~abuwhu * [They rendered it waste, and made it desolate: see yabaAbN]. (A.)

yabaAbN *
Vacant; in which there is nothing; (Sh;) in which there is no one. (T.) A^aroDN ybAbN A land that is in a state of rain, or waste, uninhabited, depopulated, deserted, desolate, in a state the contrary of flourishing: (S, K:) an uninhabited land, accord. to some. (Msb.) xaraAbN ybAbN: in this case, the latter word is merely an imitative sequent to the former: (Sh, Msb:) or it is not so; (S;) [and therefore the meaning is A very desolate waste, or the like; ybAb being added to strengthen the signification of xrAb: or merely a waste, or the like; ybAb being an explicative adjunct]. daAruhumo xaraAbo yabaAbo laA HaArisa walaA baAbo [Their dwelling is desolate, vacant; there is (to it) neither guard nor door]. (A.) HawoDN ybAbN A tank, or cistern, that is empty; containing no water. (A.) A^amosaY mina AlA^aniysi ybAbFA It became devoid of inhabitants: occurring in a verse of Ibn-Abee-Rabee'ah. (TA.)

1 yabisa * , aor. yayobasu (S, M, A, Msb, K) and yaAbasu (K) and yayobisu, (S, M, Msb, K,) which latter is extr., (S, M, K,) so that it is like yay^isa, (TA,) inf. n. yubosN (S, M, Msb *) and yabasN (M, Msb, * TA) and yabosN (M) and yubuwsapN, (K [but not there said to be an inf. n., being only mentioned there in an explanation of the word yabasN, and accord. to general rule it would be an inf. n. of yabusa, which is probably an obsolete form,]) It was, or became, dry; or it dried, or dried up; after having been moist, humid, succulent, or the like: (A, Msb, K:) or, [rather,] it was, or became, dry; or it dried, or dried up: and also, [but perhaps tropically,] it was, or became, stiff, rigid, tough, firm, resisting pressure, or hard: [contr. of raTuba:] yubosN signifying the contr. of ruTuwbapN: (M:) yubuwsapN is a quality which necessarily implies difficulty of assuming form and of becoming separated and of becoming united: (KT:) and ↓ Ait~abasa, (S, M, K,) of the measure AifotaEala, (S,) the Y being changed into t, (M,) as well as [its original form] Aiytabasa, (TA [there written Atabasa because it has the conjunction wa prefixed to it]) aor. [of the former] yat~abisu and [of the latter] yaAtabisu, (M,) signifies the same as yabisa: (M, K:) or is quasipass. of ↓ yab~asahu [and therefore signifies it became dried, or dried up; &c.]; (Ibn-Es-Sarráj, S;) [as also ↓ tyb~s, occurring in the TA, art. Eks.] You say, yabisa Aln~abaAtu [The plant, or herbage, became dry; &c.] (S, K.) And yabisati AlA^aroDu The land lost its water and moisture; its water and moisture went away. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence, yabisato TabiyEatuhu (assumed tropical:) He became costive. And] yabisa maA bayonahumaA (tropical:) [That friendship which was between them two became withered; (see 2, and see also varFY;) i. e.,] they became disunited, each from the other; the bond of friendship that united them, each to the other, became severed; syn. taqaATaEaA. (A, TA.) ― -b3- Hence also, (M,) ↓ Aiybaso, (so in a copy of the M [agreeably with an explanation of its part. n. yaAbisN, q. v., and in a copy of the A written Ayobaso,]) or A^ayobiso, [from A^ayobasa,] like A^akorimo, (K,) (tropical:) Be thou silent; or cease thou from speaking: (M, A, K:) said to a man. (M.)

2 yb~shu * , (S, A, K;) inf. n. tayobiysN, (S,) He dried it; made it dry; [&c.; see 1;] (S, A, K;) as also ↓ A^ayobasahu. (M, A, K.) ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] A^uEiy*uka biA@ll~`hi A^ano tuyab~isa raHimFA maboluwlapF (tropical:) [I pray that thou mayest be preserved by God from thy withering a freshened tie of relationship]. (A, TA.) And laA tuwbisi Alv~araY bayoniY wabayonaka (tropical:) [Wither not the fresh and vigorous friendship, between me and thee; i. e., sever not thou the firm bond of friendship that unites me and thee: see yabisa maA bayonahumaA; and see also varFY]. (A, TA.)
3 yAbshu * (assumed tropical:) He treated him with dryness and hardness, or niggardliness; syn. qaAsaHahu; (L, K, art. qsH;) i. e. EAmlh bAlybs wAl$d~h. (TK, in that art.) [See yaAbisN.]

4 Aybst AlA^aroDu *
The land had its plants or herbage, (A,) or its leguminous plants, (Yaakoob, S, K,) drying up, or dried up: (Yaakoob, S, A, K:) or became abundant in its dry plants or herbage. (M.) ― -b2- Aybst Aln~aAqapu The she-camel became milkless. (TA, voce waj~abato.) ― -b3- Aybs Alqawomu The people journeyed in the land: (K:) or in the dry land; (TA;) like as you say A^ajorazuwA from AlA^aroDu Aljuruzu. (S, TA.) ― -b4- A^ayobiso: see 1, last signification. -A2- Aybshu: see 2, in two places.
5 tayab~asa see 1.
8 Ait~abasa * and Aiytabasa , aor. yat~abisu and yaAtabisu: see 1.
yabosN * : see 1: -A2- and see yaAbisN, throughout.
yubosN * : see 1: -A2- and see yaAbisN, in two places.
yabasN * : see 1: -A2- and see yaAbisN, throughout.
yabisN * : see yaAbisN.

yabaAsN * : see yaAbisN. -A2- yabaAsi, like qiTaAmi, [as a proper name,] The pudendum; syn. Als~awo'apu: or the anus; syn. Alfunoduwrapu; (K, TA [in one copy of the K, Alqunoduwrapu; and in the CK, Alqinoda'owapu;]) i. e., AlAisotu: on the authority of IAar. (TA.)
yabuwsN * : see yaAbisN; for the latter, throughout.
yabiysN * : see yaAbisN; for the latter, throughout.

yaAbisN *
Dry, or dried up, after having been moist, humid, succulent, or the like: (A, Msb, K:) or, [rather,] dry, or dried up, or exsiccated: and also, [but perhaps tropically,] stiff, rigid, tough, firm, resisting pressure, or hard: [see 1:] (M:) pl. yub~asN (M) and ↓ yabosN, which latter is like rakobN as pl. of rAkibN: (ISk, S, Msb:) and ↓ yubosN is a dial. form. of yabosN: (A'Obeyd, S:) or yabosN is [rather] a quasi-pl. of yaAbisN, as is also ↓ yabasN: (M:) or this last is used by poetic license for yabosN: (TA:) also, (S, M,) ↓ yabosN signifies the same as yaAbisN, (S, M, Msb, K,) as also ↓ yabasN, (M,) and ↓ yabisN, (M, K,) and ↓ yabiysN, (K,) and ↓ yabowsN, (M,) and ↓ yabaAsN, (TA,) and ↓ A^ayobasu: (K:) or ↓ yabasN signifies dry from its origin, not having been known moist: (K:) but ↓ yabosN is applied to a thing dry after having been known to be moist: (TA:) and as to the path of Moses, [to which the former of the last two epithets is applied in the Kur. xx. 79,] it had never been known as a path either moist or dry, for God only showed it to them created such; but the epithet is also read with sukoon to the b, because, though it had not been a path, it was a place wherein had been water and which had dried up: (K, TA:) the latter reading is that of El-Hasan El-Basree: and El-Aamash read the word with kesr to the b: (TA:) Th [however] says, (S,) you say ↓ HaTabN yabosN, dry fire-wood, as though it were so naturally: (S, Msb:) [and J says,] ↓ yabasN signifies a place dry after having been moist; and so in the instance in the Kur. mentioned above: (S:) [and Fei says,] it signifies a place that has had in it water which has gone away; or, as Az says, a path in which is no moisture: (Msb:) [and ISd says,] ↓ yabosN and ↓ yabas signify a place that is dry: and in like manner, applied to land (A^aroD), of which the water and pasturage have dried up: and the latter, so applied, (assumed tropical:) hard; (M;) as also yaAbisN (tropical:) applied to a stone: (A:) ↓ yabysN is [generally] applied to a plant, or herbage, as signifying dry, or dried up; (S, M, A, Msb, K;) as also [sometimes] yaAbisN; (M, K;) the former being of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure faAEilN: (Msb:) or it is so applied to herbs, or leguminous plants, of the sort termed A^aHoraAr [that are eaten without being cooked, or that are slender and succulent, &c.], (As, K,) and of the sort termed *ukuwr [that are hard and thick, or thick and rough, &c.]; (As, TA;) and [so As, in the TA; and so in some copies of the K; but in the CK, or] those herbs and leguminous plants that become scattered when they dry up; (As, K;) as also ↓ yubosN and ↓ yabosN; (TA;) but not to what is dry of the HaliY~ and Sil~iyaAn and Halamap. (As, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Almafoluwju AlyaAbisu Al$~iq~i (assumed tropical:) The palsied of whom the half is without sensation and without motion. (Mgh.) And rajulN yaAbisN mina Als~ukori (AHn) app. meaning (assumed tropical:) A man as though he were dead and dried up in consequence of much intoxication. (M.) [And yAabisu AlT~abiyEapi (assumed tropical:) Costive.] And sakoraAnu yaAbisN (assumed tropical:) Intoxicated so much as not to speak; as though the wine had dried him up by its heat. (M.) And ↓ A^ataAnN yabosapN (IAar, M) and ↓ yabasapN (Th, M) (assumed tropical:) A she-ass dry and lean. (M.) And ↓ $aApN yabosN and ↓ yabasN (AO, S, M, K) (assumed tropical:) A ewe, or she-goat, without milk: (AO, S, M, K:) or whose milk has stopped, and her udder become dry. (M.) And ↓ A_imoraA^apN yabasapN (assumed tropical:) A woman who has no milk: pl. yabasaAtN and A^ayobaAsN and [quasi-pl. n.] yaAbisN [like jaAmilN and baAqirN]. (TA, from the Moheet.) And ↓ EiroqN yabiysN (assumed tropical:) [A dry duct], meaning, penis. (Lh, M.) And $aEarN yaAbisN (tropical:) Hair upon which no effect is produced by moistening with water nor with oil; (A, TA *;) which is the worst sort thereof. (TA.) And ↓ yabiysu AlmaA='i (tropical:) Dry sweat: (M, A:) or [simply] sweat. (AA, S, K.) And rajulN yaAbisN and ↓ yabiysN (tropical:) A man having little good: (A:) and AimoroA^apN yaAbisapN and ↓ yabiysN (A, TA) and ↓ yabasN (S, K, TA) (tropical:) a woman having little good: (A:) or in whom is no good: (K, TA:) or who does not cause one to obtain any good. (S.) And ↓ bayonahumaA varFY A^ayobasu (tropical:) Between them two is disunion. (A, TA.)

A^ayobasu * [comp. and superl. of yaAbisN]. ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] A^ayobasu mina AlS~axori (tropical:) Harder than rock. (A.) -A2- See also yaAbisN, near the beginning and at the end. -A3- AlA^ayobasu, as a subst., not an epithet, (AHeyth,) The part of the shin-bone, in the middle of the shank, which, when pressed, pains one, (AHeyth, K,) and when it is broken, the leg is lost: (AHeyth:) or AlA^ayobasaAni signifies the parts of the two shanks upon which is no flesh: (S:) or the parts of the two shanks of a horse upon which the flesh is dry, or tough: (AO:) or the shank-bones (M, TA) of the fore leg and hind leg: (TA:) or what appears of these: (M, TA:) or the parts above the kaEobAani and zanodaAni [app. here meaning the two ankles and wrists]: (A:) pl. A^ayaAbisu: (S, K:) which is also applied to such parts as are like the hock, or hough, and the shank. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, the pl., Hard things upon which swords are tried. (K.)
A^aroDN muwbisapN * [originally muyobisapN] Land of which the plants, or herbage, are drying up, or dried up. (A.)
riyjN miybaAsN * [A very drying wind]. (TA, voce nakobaA='u.)

Q. 1 yaronaA^a liHoyatahu * (K, TA; in the CK, [erroneously,] taran~aA^a;) He dyed his beard with yrn~A^. (K.) A strange verb as to its form, (K,) which [except in its final vowel] is that of an aorist, though it is a preterite. (TA.) Mentioned in the L in art. rnA^ (q. v.), on the authority of IJ; and there also by ISd; and AHei and others assert the Y to be augmentative. [If so, the verb is a quasi-quadriliteral-radical word.] F follows Sgh, in mentioning it here. (TA.)

yuran~aA^N * (S, K) and yaran~aA^N and yuran~aA='N (K) and yuran~aA (without ') and (accord. to [the Bári', as mentioned in] the TA, art. rnA^,) yaronaA^N and yuronaA^N and (accord. to MF, who omits the two forms here immediately preceding,) yaran~aA'N and yaran~aA, without ', (TA,) i. q. Hin~aA'N (S, K) [The plant Lawsonia inermis]. See also art. rnA^, where the word is written [erroneously in my opinion] yarun~aA^N. Accord. to IB (not IJ [as in the CK]), the may only be omitted when the word is pronounced with dammeh to the Y. (TA.)

1 yasara * , aor. yabosiru, [respecting the form of which see the same verb in a different sense below,] inf. n. yasorN and yasarN [and mayosuwrN (see yusorN below)], He was, or became, gentle, and tractable, submissive, manageable, or easy; (M, K;) said of a man, and of a horse: (M:) and yusira [app. signifies the same: and] is said of speech, and of a thing or an affair; signifying, [when relating to the former,] it was gentle, or [when relating to the latter,] easy; like suEida Alr~ajulu [as
syn. with saEida], and nuHisa [as syn. with naHisa]. (Bd, xvii. 30.) See also tys~r. ― -b2- yasarato, said of a woman: see A^ayosarato -A2- yasura, aor.
yasura , It (a thing) was, or became, little in quantity: (A, Msb:) contemptible; paltry; of no weight or worth. (A.) -A3- yasaraniY, aor. yayosiruniY, (AHn, M, K,) inf. n. yasorN, (AHn, M,) He (a man, AHn, M) came on, or from the direction of, my left hand. (AHn, M, K.) See also 3. -A4- yasara, [aor. yayosiru, inf. n. yasorN,] He divided anything into parts, or portions. (TA.) You say, yasarotu Aln~aAqapa I divided the flesh of the she-camel into parts or portions. (TA.) And yasaruwA Aljazuwra They slaughtered the she-camel and divided its limbs, (S,) or portions, (TA,) among themselves; (S, TA;) as also, accord. to Aboo-'Omar ElJarmee, ↓ A_it~asaruwhaA, aor. yat~asiruwnahaA, inf. n. A_it~isaArN; and he adds that some people say, yaA^otasiruwnahaA, inf. n. A@notisaArN, with hemz; and humo muw^otasiruwna; like as they say in the case of A_it~aEada. (S.) Soheym Ibn-Wetheel El-Yarboo'ee says,
A^aquwlu lahumo biAl$~iEobi A_i*o yayosiruwnaniY
A^alamo tayoy^asuwA A^an~iY A@bonu faArisi zahodami
[I say to them, in the ravine, when they divide me among themselves, deciding what shares they shall severally have in me, Know ye not that I am the son of the rider of Zahdam, and that ye may obtain a great ransom for me?] for capture had befallen him, and they played with [gaming-] arrows for him. (S, TA. [but in the latter, instead of tayoy^asuwA, we find taEolamuwA, which signifies the same.]) You say also, ↓ A_it~asaruwA, aor. yat~asiruwna and yaA^otasiruwna; (K;) and ↓ tayAasaruwA; (M, K;) They divided among themselves the slaughtered camel. (M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] yasara, aor. yayosiru, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) in the [second] Y is not suppressed as it is in yaEidu and its cöordinates [having w for the first radical], (S,) and yiysaru, like yiyjalu, in the dial. of the Benoo-Asad, (TA,) inf. n. yasorN, (M, TA,) or mayosirN, (A,) He played at the game called Almayosir; (M, Msb, K;) he played with gamingarrows. (S, A, Msb.)

2 ys~rhu * , (inf. n. tayosiyrN, M, &c.) He (God, A, Msb) made it, or rendered it, easy; facilitated it. (M, A, Mgh, Msb, K.) You say, yus~irato EalayohaA AlwilaAdapu The act of bringing forth was rendered easy to her. (A.) ― -b2- He made his circumstances ample; he made his condition, or his way or course [lika*aA to such a thing], easy, or smooth: (Sb, M:) he accommodated, adapted, or disposed, him, liloyusoraY [to easy things, or affairs, or circumstances; or to the easier, or easiest, way]: (S. A, [in the latter of which this is given as a proper, not tropical, signification:]) (tropical:) he prepared, or made ready, him or it, lika*aA for such a thing. (A [in which this signification is said to be tropical.]) tayosiyrN relates to both good and evil: (M, K:) as in the following instances in the Kur; [xcii. 7, 10;] fasanuyas~iruhu liloyusoraY, and liloEusoraY, (M,) [We will facilitate, or smooth, his way, or] We will accommodate him, or adapt him, or dispose him, [to a state of ease, and to a state of difficulty, or (as explained in the TA, art. Esr,) to punishment, and a difficult case:] (S, A:) or We will prepare him for paradise, and for hell: (Jel:) or We will prepare him to return to good, or righteous, conduct, [and to persevere in evil, or unrighteous, conduct; the former leading to ease, and the latter to difficulty:] (Fr, TA:) or We will prepare him for that habit of conduct which leads to ease, such as the entering paradise, and for that which leads to difficulty, such as the entering hell: from ys~r Alfarasa, meaning, he prepared the horse for riding, by saddling and bridling. (Bd.) It is said in a trad. waqado yus~ira lahu TahuwrN (assumed tropical:) And water for ablution had been prepared and put for him. (TA.) ― -b3- yas~ara Alr~ajulu, (inf. n. tayosiyrN, K,) The man's camels, and his sheep or goats, brought forth with ease, (IAar, M, K), and none of them perished. (IAar, M.) ― -b4- yas~arati Alganamu The sheep, or goats, abounded in milk, (S, M, A, K,) and in like manner, AlA_ibilu the camels, (M,) and [so in the S, M, A, but in the K or] in offspring: (S, M, A, K:) and they brought forth: and they were ready to bring forth: and they abounded. (TA.) A poet (namely Aboo-Useydeh Ed-Debeeree, TA) says,
humaA say~idaAnaA yazoEumaAni wA_in~amaA
yasuwdaAninaA A^ano yas~arato ganamaA humaA
(S, M) They two are our two chiefs, as they assert; but they are only our chiefs inasmuch as their sheep, or goats, abound in milk and in offspring. (TA.) ― -b5- See also A^ayosarato.

3 yAsrhu * , [inf. n. muyaAsarapN] He was gentle towards him; acted gently towards him; treated him with gentleness; syn. laAyanahu: (M, A, K:) he was easy, or facile, with him; syn. saAhalahu. (S, K.) Ex., cited by Th, from a poem: A_ino yaAsarotahumo yasaruwA If thou treat them with gentleness, they become gently. (M.) And yaAsara Al$~ariyka He was easy, or facile, with the partner. (TA, from a trad.) -A2- yAsr, (inf. n. muyaAsarapN, K,) He took the left-hand side or direction; (S, M, A, Msb, K;) as also ↓ tyAsr; (S, Msb, K;) which latter is the contr. of tyAmn: (K:) or ↓ tayaAsaruwA they took the lefthand side or direction; contr. of tayaAmanuwA. (A.) You say, yaAsiro biA^aSoHaAbika Take thou the left-hand side or direction with thy companions; (S, A;) as also tayaAsaro; but some disapprove of this latter. (S.) And yaAsara biAlqawomi He took the left-hand side or direction with the people; as also ↓ yasara bihimo aor. yayosiru; accord. to Sb. (M, TA.)

4 A^ayosarato *
She (a woman, M) brought forth with ease; she had an easy birth; (M, A, K;) as also ↓ ys~rt, (M, IKtt,) which is in like manner said of a she-camel; (M;) or, as in the copies of the K, yasarato, without teshdeed. (TA.) One says, in praying (M, A) for a pregnant woman, (A,) A^ayosarato waA^a*okarato May she have an easy birth, (Lh, M, A,) and may she bring forth a male child. (Lh, M.) See the contr., A^aEosarato. -A2- Aysr, (S, M, &c.,) aor. yuwsiru, in which the [radical] Y is changed into w because it is quiescent and preceded by damm, (S,) inf. n. A_iysaArN (M, Mgh, K) and yusorN; (M, K;) accord. to Kr and Lh, but correctly the latter is a simple subst., (M,) He became possessed of competence, or sufficiency; or of richness, or wealth, or opulence; (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) and abundance. (Msb.) -A3- A^ayomanotu A_ibiliY waA^ayosarotuhaA I put my camels aside on the right hand and the left. (A.)

5 tys~r *
It (a thing, M, Msb) was, or became, facilitated, or easy; (M, A, Msb, K, TA;) contr. of difficult, hard, strait, or intricate; (TA;) as also ↓ Astysr. (M, A, Msb, K.) You say, A^axa*onaA maA tayas~ara, and ↓ maA A@sotayosara, We took what was easy [of obtainment, or of attainment]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., respecting the eleemosinary tax called wayajoEalu mEahaA $aAtayoni A_ini, zakaAp lahu A^awo Ei$ariyna dirohamFA ↓ A@sotayosarataA And he shall put with it, or them, two sheep, or goats, if they be easy to him [to give], or twenty dirhems. (TA.) And in the Kur, [ii. 192,] mina AlhadoYi ↓ famaA A@sotayosara What is easy [to give], of camels and kine and sheep or goats: or, as some say, either a camel or a cow or a sheep or goat. (M, TA.) ― -b2- Also, tys~r lahu, (S, TA,) and lh ↓ Astysr, (S, K, TA,) (assumed tropical:) It (a thing, or an affair, K) was, or became, prepared, or made ready for him: (S, K, TA:) [and he prepared himself for it.] It is said in a trad., qado tayas~araA liloqitaAli (assumed tropical:) They had both prepared themselves, or made themselves ready, for fight. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b3- tayas~arati AlbilaAdu (tropical:) The countries became abundant in herbage, or in the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life. (TA, from a trad.)

6 tayaAsaruwA * [They were gentle, or acted gently, one towards another; they treated one another with gentleness: (see 3, of which it is the quasipass.)] they were easy, or facile, one with another; syn. tsAhlwA; (K, * TA;) tayaAsurN is the contr. of taEaAsurN. (S, art. Esr.) It is said in a trad., tayaAsaruwA fiY AlS~adaAqi Be ye easy, or facile, not exorbitant, one with another, with respect to dowry. (TA.) -A2- See also 3. -A3- And see 1, latter part.
8 A_iyotasara see 1, in two places.
10 A_isotayosara see 5, in five places.

yasorN * (TA) and ↓ yasarN, (M, A, K, TA,) [each an inf. n. (see 1) used as an epithet,] and yaAsirN, (K, TA,) Easy and gentle in tractableness, submissiveness, or manageableness; applied to a man and to a horse: (TA:) or [simply] easy; facile; (M, A, K;) as also ↓ yusorN (TA) and yasiyrN, (Msb), this last being syn. with hay~inN, (S, K,) and signifying not difficult, gayoru EasiyrK, (A,) and ↓ mayosuwrN [respecting which see also EusorN, pl. mayaAsiyru]. (A.) Hence, ↓ yasaraAtN, pl. of yasorapN and yasarapN, applied to the legs of a beast, signifies Easy: (M:) or light, or active, legs of a beast: (S, TA:) or light, or active, and obedient, legs of a beast of carriage: (A:) or the legs of a she-camel: and you say also, A_in~a qawaAy^ima h`*aA Alfarasi yasaraAtN xifaAfN, meaning, verily the legs of this horse are obedient and light or active. (TA.) [Hence also,] wilaAdapN yasorN [An easy birth, or bringing forth]. (A.) And waladato waladahaA yasorFA She brought forth her child easily: (M, K *:) said of a woman: (M:) or ↓ yasarFA. (CK.) And it is said in a trad., ↓ A_in~a h`*aA Ald~iyna yusorN Verily this religion is easy; liberal; one having little straitness. (TA.) You say also, ↓ xu*o mayosuwrahu wadaEo maEosuwrahu [Take thou what is easy thereof, and leave thou what is difficult]. (A.) And ↓ mayosuwrN is applied to a saying, or speech: (A:) so in the Kur. xvii. 30; meaning, gentle; (Bd, Jel;) easy: (Jel:) or ↓ quwolN mayosuwrN means prayer for mayosuwr, i. e., for yusor [q. v.]. (Bd.) ― -b2- fatolN yasorN [The twisting a rope or cord towards the left, by rolling it against the body from right to left; or] the twisting downwards, by extending the right hand towards the body [and so rolling the rope or cord downwards against the body or thigh, which is the usual way of twisting]; (S, A *, K;) contr. of $azorN. (M, A, TA) ― -b3- TaEonN yasorN The thrusting, or piercing, [straight forward; or] opposite the face: (S, M, K:) opposed to $azorN, which is from one's right and one's left. (TA.) See an ex. voce $azarahu.

yusorN * [Easiness; facility;] contr. of EusorN; (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓ yusurN; (S, Msb, TA;) [and ↓ yusoraY; (see 3, where it is variously explained;)] and ↓ mayosuwrN is the contr. of maEosuwrN, [and therefore signifies as above; or easy; facile;] (S;) or this last signifies, (accord. to the lexicologists, M,) what is made easy; or facilitated; or (accord. to Sb, M, [but see maEaquwlN,]) it is an inf. n. of the measure mafoEuwlN, (M, K,) [used in the sense of yusorN as explained above,] of the same kind as [its contr.] maEosuwrN; and Abu-l-Hasan says, that this is the truth; for it has no unaugmented verb, and inf. ns. of this measure are not of verbs which are in use, but only of imaginary unaugmented triliteral-radical verbs, as in the case of majoluwdN, which is [really] from tajal~ada. (M.) For examples of yusorN, see EusorN. ― -b2- Also, (accord. to the M; but in the K, or; and in both of these lexicons the signification here following is placed first;) and in like manner, ↓ yusurN, (K,) and ↓ yasaArN, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and ↓ yasaArapN, (S, K,) and ↓ mayosarapN, and ↓ mayosurapN, (S, M, K,) of which last Sb says that it is like masorubapN and ma$orubapN in not being after the manner of the verb, [but after that of the simple substantive,] (M,) and ↓ mayosirapN, (K.) Easiness [of circumstances]; (M, K;) competence, or sufficiency; or richness, or wealth, or opulence; (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) abundance; (Msb;) [in these senses, also, contr. of EusorN;] and ↓ yusoraY signifies [the same; or] easy things or affairs or circumstances; contr. of EusoraY; as also ↓ mayosarapN. (TA, art. Esr.) You say also, ↓ A^anoZironiY Hat~aY yasaAri [Grant thou me a delay until I shall be in a state of easiness of circumstances, &c.]; in which the last word is indecl., with kesr for its termination, because it is altered from the inf. n., which is Almayosarapu. (S.) In the Kur. [ii. 280,] some read, ↓ fanaZirapN A_ilaY mayosurihi [Then let there be a postponement, or delay, until his being in a state of easiness of circumstances]: but Akh says, that this is not allowable; for there is no noun of the measure mafoEulN [of this kind]: as to makorumN and maEuwnN, [it is said that] they are pls. [virtually though not in the language of the grammarians] of makorumapN and maEuwnapN. (S.) [On this point, see maA^olukN, voce A^aluwkN.] -A2- See also yasorN, in two places. -A3- Euwdu yusorK: see Euwdu A^usorK, in art. A^sr.

yasarN * : see yasorN. ― -b2- Made easy, or facilitated; i. q. muyas~arN: (assumed tropical:) prepared: (K:) or [the game called] Almayosir prepared: or, as some say, (assumed tropical:) anything prepared. (M.) -A2- A^aEosaru yasarN A man who works, or does anything, with both his hands [alike]; ambidextrous; ambidexter: (S, M, Msb:) and ↓ A^aEosaru A^ayosaru occurs in a trad., accord. to one relation; but the former is the correct expression: (A'Obeyd:) and the fem. is EasoraA='u yasarapN: (M:) explained before, in art. Esr. (K.) -A3- See also yaAsirN, in six places.
yusurN * : see yusorN, in two places.
yasorapN * : see yasaArN, throughout.
yusoraY * : see yusorN, in two places. -A2- See also A^ayosaru. -A3- See also yasaArN, throughout.

yasaArN * : see yusorN, in two places. -A2- Also, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) and ↓ yisaArN, (M, Msb, K,) the former of which is the more chaste, (ISk, IAmb, IF, M, Msb, K *,) or the latter is so, (IDrd, M, K,) or the latter is a variation used for the sake of assimilation to [its syn.] $imaAlN, (Sgh, TA,) or it is vulgar, (IKt, Msb,) and not allowable, (S,) or J is in error in disallowing it, (K,) or it is disapproved because the incipient Y with kesr is deemed difficult to pronounce, (M, TA,) but there are three other words commencing like it, namely, yiwaAmN, an inf. n. of yaAwamahu, though this is disallowed by some, and yiEaArN, pl. of yaEorN, and yisaAfN, a proper name of a man, also pronounced with fet-h [to the Y]; (TA;) and another form is ↓ yas~aArN; (Sgh, K;) contr. of yamiynN; (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) and so is ↓ yusoraY of yumnaY, (M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and yasorapN of yamonapN, (M, A, Msb, K,) and ↓ mayosarapN of mayomanapN, (A, Msb, K,) and ↓ A^ayosaru of A^ayomanu: (S:) yasaArN and ↓ yusoraY signify The left [hand, or arm, or foot, or leg, or] limb: and the same two words, and ↓ yasorapN and ↓ mayosarapN, the left, meaning the left side or direction or relative location or place: (Msb:) and ↓ A^ayosaru, the left side: or a person [or thing] that is on the left side: (Msb, art. ymn:) [and ↓ mayosarapN the left wing of an army:] the pl. of yasaArN is yusurN (Lh, M, K) and yusorN, (K,) or yusarN; (AHn, M;) which last is [also] pl. of ↓ yusoraY; (TA;) [and the pl. of ↓ mayosarapN is mayaAsiru.] You say, qaEada fulaAnN ↓ yasorapF Such a one sat on the left side. (S.) And ↓ qaEaduwA yamonapF wayasorapF, (A, Msb *,) and EalaY yamiynK wayasaArK, and ↓ AlyumonaY waAloyusoraY, and ↓ Almayomanapi waAlomayosarapi, (A,) or yamiynFAwayasaArFA, and Eani Aloyamiyni waEani AloyasaAri, and AlyumonaY waAloyusoraY, and Almayomanapi waAlomayosarapi, meaning, They sat on the right side and on the left. (Msb.) And ↓ wal~aAhu mayaAsirahu [He turned his left parts towards him]. (A.)
yisaArN * : see yasaArN.
yasuwrN * : see yaAsirN, in two places.
yasiyrN * : see yasorN. -A2- Little, or small, in quantity, petty: (S, A, K:) mean, contemptible; paltry; of no weight or worth. (A.) -A3- See also yaAsirN.
yasaArapN * : see yusorN.
yas~aArN * : see yasaArN.

yaAsirN * : see yasorN, first signification. -A2- [Taking the left-hand side or direction: or coming on, or from the direction of, the left hand of a person:] contr. of yaAminN. (S.) -A3- [Dividing a thing into parts, or portions.] ― -b2- [Hence,] The slaughterer of a camel: (K, TA:) because he divides its flesh into portions: (TA:) the person who superintends the division of the slaughtered camel (M, K) for the game called Almayosir: (K:) pl. [yaAsiruwna and] A^ayosaArN: (M, K:) A'Obeyd says, I have heard them put yaAsirN in the place of yasarN, [for the explanations of which see what follows,] and ↓ yasarN in the place of yaAsirN, (M,) or ↓ yasarN and yaAsirN signify the same: and the pl. is A^ayosaArN: (S, A:) yaAsirN signifies [as explained above, and also] a person who plays with gaming-arrows, (S, Msb, TA,) [at the
game called Almayosir,] for a slaughtered camel; because he is one of those who occasion the slaughter of the camel; and the pl. is [as above and] yaAsiruwna: (TA:) and ↓ yasarN, i. q. DariybN [which signifies the same; and the person who is entrusted, as deputy, with the disposal of the arrows in the game above mentioned, and who shuffles them in the ribaAbap:] and, [as quasi-pl. of yaAsirN, like as xadamN is of xaAdimN,] a party assembled together at the game called Almayosir: (M, K:) pl. A^ayosaArN: (M:) and ↓ yasiyrN and ↓ yasuwrN signify one who contends with another at a game of hazard; syn. qaAmirN: (K:) or ↓ yasarN and ↓ yasuwrN, and also yaAsirN, are applied to one who has, or to whom pertains, a gamingarrow. (IAar, TA.)
A^ayosaru * [More, and most, easy, or facile; fem. yusoraY]. -A2- See also yasaArN.

mwsirN * [originally muyosirN,] Possessing competence, or sufficiency; or rich, or wealthy, or opulent: (M, K:) pl. mayaAsiyru: (Sb, M, K:) [like mafaAliysu, pl. of mufolisN; and mafaATiyru, pl. of mufoTirN; as though the sing. were mayosuwrN:] but by rule it should be muwsiruwna, for the masc., and muwsiraAtN for the fem. (Abu-l-Hasan, M.)
mayosurN * : see yusorN.

mayosirN * The game, or play, with unfeathered and headless arrows; (M, K;) the game of hazard which the Arabs play with such arrows; (S, Mgh, Msb;) a game of the Arabs, played [by ten men,] with ten unfeathered and headless arrows: they first slaughtered a camel, [bought on credit, (see below, in this paragraph,)] and divided it into ten portions, or, as some say, [agreeably with what follows,] into twenty-eight: the first arrow was called Alfa*~u, and had [one notch and] one portion of the slaughtered camel: the second, Alt~awo'amu, and had [two notches and] two portions: the third, Alr~aqiybu, and had [three notches and] three portions: the fourth, AlHilosu, and had [four notches and] four portions: the fifth, Aln~aAfisu, and had [five notches and] five portions; or, as some say, this was the fourth: the sixth, Almusobilu, and had [six notches and] six portions: the seventh, AlmuEal~aY, which was the highest of them, having [seven notches and] seven portions: the eighth and ninth and tenth were called Als~afiyHu and AlmaniyHu and Alwagodu; and these three had no portions: [the players to whom these three fell had to pay for the slaughtered camel: (see Almusobilu:) whence it appears, that if the camel was divided into ten portions, (see rayomN,) the game must have continued after all these were won, until it was seen whose were the eighth and ninth and tenth arrows; and it seems to be the general opinion that this was the case:] the camel being slaughtered, they collected together the ten arrows, and put them into the ribaAbap, a thing resembling a quiver (kinaAnap), and turned them round about or shuffled them (A^ajaAluwhaA): [or they employed a person, whom they called HuroDap, to do this:] then they put them into the hand of the judge (AlHakam), who took them forth one after another in the name of one after another of the party; [or they commissioned the HuroDah to do so;] and each took of the portions of the slaughtered camel according to his arrow; but those to whose lots fell the arrows without portions were obliged to pay the price of the slaughtered camel: with the flesh of which they afterwards fed the poor; and him who would not engage with them in the game they reproached, and called a baram: (Sefeenet Er-Rághib, printed at Boolák; p. 637:) [see also raqiybN, and DariybN, and Ea$orN:] or any game of hazard; or play for stakes, or wagers: (K:) so that even the game of children with walnuts is included under this name by Mujáhid in his explanation of verse 216 of chap. ii. of the Kur.: (TA:) or anything in which is risk, or hazard: (Kull, p. 321:) or the game of tricktrack, backgammon, or tables; syn. narodN: (Sgh, K:) and chess was called by 'Alee the mayosir of the Persians, or foreigners: (TA:) or the slaughtered camel for which they played: for when they desired to play, they bought on credit a camel for slaughter, and slaughtered it, and divided it into twentyeight portions, or ten portions; and when one [of the arrows] after another came forth [from the ribaAbap] in the name of one man after another, the gain of him for whom came forth those to which belonged portions appeared, and the fine of him for whom came forth [any of the arrows called] the gufol: (K:) so called as though it were a place of division: and so used by the poet Lebeed, who speaks of a fat mayosir. (TA.)
mayosarapN * : see yusorN, in two places. -A2- See also yasaArN, in four places.
mayosurapN * : see yusorN.
mayosirapN * : see yusorN.

muyas~arN *
Prepared; disposed; made easy, or facile. So in the following words of a trad.: fakul~N muyas~arN limaA xuliqa lahu [And every one is prepared, &c., for that for which he is created]. (TA.) -A2- I. q. zumaAwarodN [q. v.]; (Mgh, K;) app. a post-classical word; so called because easily taken; (Mgh;) in Persian, called nuwaAlaho [or nawaAlaho], (Mgh, K,) and in Egypt termed luqomapu AlqaADiY. (TA.)
muyas~irN * , applied to a man, (S, TA,) Having numerous offspring of sheep or goats [and therefore much milk]; (TA;) contr. of mujan~ibN. (S, TA.)
mayosuwrN * : see yasorN, in three places: -A2- and see also yusorN.
mayaAsiru * She-camels that bring forth easily. (TA.)

ya$obN *
A well known stone; [jasper; peenliarly a whitish kind thereof, found in Mount Imaus: (Golius, from Et-Teyfáshee:)] an arabicized word, from [the Persian] ya$om, q. v. (K.)

4 maA A^ayoTabahu *
i. q. maA A^aToyabahu: (K:) a dial. form of the latter, or formed from it by transposition: (TA:) and in like manner A^ayoTibo bihi, i. q. A^aToyibo bihi: [both signifying How good, sweet, delicious, or pleasant, is he, or it]. (TA, art. Tyb.)

A^ayoTabu *
i. q. A^Toyabu [More, or most, good, sweet, delicious, or pleasant: and pure]: a correct and chaste dial. form of the latter word. (Ex., from a trad., Ealayokumo biAlA^asowadi minohu faA_in~ahu A^ayoTabuhu Keep ye to the black thereof; (i. e., of the fruit of the A^raAk;) for it is the best of it. But some deny its being a dial. form, [holding it to be formed by transposition]. (TA.) ― -b2- A^aqobalati Al$~aApu fiY A^ayoTabatihaA, and A^ayoTab~atihaA, (the latter form from AZ, TA,) The sheep, or goat, came in the vehemence of her lust for the male. (K.) See also art. Tyb.

1 yafaxahu * , (K,) aor.
yafaxa , because of the guttural letter, or
yafuxa , accord. to the common rule observed in the K, or
yafixa , as though it were of the same class as waEada, (TA,) [the last is probably the most correct form, as yaA^ofixuhu is the aor. of A^afaxahu, of which yafaxahu is a dial. form,] He, or it, hit him, or hurt him, on the part of his head called the yaAfuwx. (K.)

yaAfuwxN * [The top of the head;] the part where the anterior and posterior bones of the head meet: [see yaA^ofuwxN, of which it is a dial. form:] pl. yawaAfiyxu. (TA.) ISd regards this form of pl. as an indication that the Y is a radical letter, and therefore mentions it in this art.; (TA;) [and F says the same in art. A^fx: but see that art.]. ― -b2- mas~a biyaAfuwxihi Als~imaAka (assumed tropical:) [He touched Spica Virginis, or Arcturus, with the top of his head]. (A.) ― -b3- waTiy^a fulaAnN yawaAfiyxa Alquruwmi (assumed tropical:) Such a one had lordship and eminence given to him. (A.) ― -b4- SadaEuwA yaAfuwxa All~ayoli (tropical:) i. q. A^adolajuwA [They journeyed in the night; &c.] (A.) [See also art. A^fx.]

mayofuwxN *
Hit, or hurt, on the part of his head called the yaAfuwx. (K.)

yaAquwtN * , [coll. gen. n., The sapphire, of whatever variety: the ruby, oriental ruby, or red sapphire, also called yAqwtN A^aHomaru; of which there are several varieties, whereof one is the carbuncle; also called yAqwtN jamoriY~N: the sapphire, commonly so called, or blue sapphire, also called yAqwtN A^azoraqu: and the topaz, oriental topaz, or yellow sapphire, also called yAqwtN A^aSofaru: the jacinth, or hyacinth, accord. to Golius, who observes, as on the authority of the Teyfáshee, that by this name are called various gems of the East; four species thereof being enumerated; the red, the yellow, or gold-coloured, the blue, or azure, and the white: that the sapphire and the chrysolite are also thus called: but that, by the word used absolutely, the red jacinth, or hyacinth, commonly called the ruby, is meant: which last remark is agreeable with modern usage:] a well known gem; (K;) of which there are many varieties, (TA,) the most excellent whereof is that called AlyAqwtu AlA^aHomaru Alr~um~aAniY~u, (K,) also called AlbahoramaAniY~u; [the finest kind of ruby or carbuncle;] said to be brought from Sarandeeb [or Ceylon]: it has the property of exhilarating, and of conjoining [separated friends]; (TA;) and is profitable for disturbance of the mind (occasioned by the black bile, TA) and palpitation, and weakness of the heart and stomach, if drunk; [being app. reduced to powder for that purpose, as is done with some other gems in the East;] and for congealment of the blood, if hung [upon the person]: (K:) it is a Persian word, (S,) arabicized: (S, K:) of the measure faAEuwlN: n. un. with p; and pl. yawAqiytu. (S.)

1 yaqiZa * , aor.
yaqaZa , (Msb, K,) and yaquZa, aor.
yaquZa ; (Lh, K;) and in the Msb is added yaqaZa, i. e. like Daraba, which is strange; (TA;) [but this I do not find in my copy of the Msb;] inf. n. [of the first] yaqaZN (Msb, K) and yaqaZapN, (Msb, TA,) or the latter is a simple subst., (S,) and [of the second] yaqaAZapN; (Msb, K;) He waked, or woke; did not sleep, or was not sleeping. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- See also 5.
2 yaq~aZa See 4, throughout.

4 AyqZhu * (S, &c.) inf. n. A_iyqaAZN, (TA,) He awakened him, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) mino niwomihi from his sleep; (S;) as also ↓ yq~Zhu, inf. n. tayoqiyZN; (K;) and ↓ AstyqZhu. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He roused his attention, liloA^umuwri to the things, or affairs; (Msb;) as also yq~Zhu. (TA.) ― -b3- AyqZ AlgubaAra (tropical:) He dispersed the dust: (Lth:) and (assumed tropical:) he raised the dust; (Lth, S, Z;) as also ↓ yq~Zhu: (Lth, S:) or, accord. to Az, this is a mistranscription, for baq~aTa Alt~uraAba, inf. n. taboqiyTN. (TA.)

5 tyq~Z *
He became awakened; or he awaked, or awoke; (S, Msb, TA;) mino nawomihi from his sleep; (TA;) as also ↓ AstyqZ. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b2- (tropical:) His attention became roused, or he had his attention roused, liloA^amori to the thing, or affair; (Msb, * TA;) as also ↓ AstyqZ, and ↓ yaqiZa: (Msb:) he became vigilant, wary, or cautious. (TA.) You say also, A_ilaY Sawotihi ↓ huwa yasotayoqiZu (tropical:) [He has his attention roused at his voice, to listen thereto]. (TA.)

10 A_isotayoqaZa
AstyqZ: see 5, in three places. ― -b2- (tropical:) It (a woman's anklet or other ornament) made a sound or sounds: (K, TA:) like as one says [in the contr. case], naAma, meaning “ its sound, or sounds, ceased, ” by reason of the fulness of the leg. (TA.) -A2- AstyqZhu: see 4.
yaqoZN * : see what next follows, in three places.

yaqiZN * and ↓ yaqoZN and ↓ yaqoZaAnN A man waking, or awake: not sleeping: (K:) or the last has this signification; (S, Msb;) and its fem. is yaqoZaY: (O, Msb, K:) the pl. (K, &c.) of the first (IB, Msb) and second, (IB,) or of the first only, for the second has no broken pl., because of the rareness of faEulN as the measure of an epithet, (Sb, TA,) is A^ayoqaAZN, (Sb, IB, Msb, K,) which is applied to women as well as to men; (O;) and the pl. of yqZAn is yiqaAZN; (IB;) and the pl. of yqZY is yaqaAZaY. (K.) ― -b2- And the first (ISk, S, Msb) and ↓ second (ISk, S) (tropical:) A man vigilant, wary, cautious, or in a state of preparation; (S, Msb;) having his attention roused: (S:) and intelligent: (Msb:) or a man having his attention much roused, very vigilant, and possessing knowledge and intelligence. (ISk.) [In the TA, each of these two epithets is said to be after the manner of the rel. n.; but they are both part. ns. from yaqiZa as syn. with tyq~Z.] You say also, Alfikori ↓ rajulN yaqoZaAnu and ↓ mutayaq~iZuhu and yaqiZuhu and ↓ yaquZuhu (tropical:) [A man vigilant in mind]. (TA.) And A_in~a fulaAnN layaqiZN (assumed tropical:) [Verily such a one is vigilant; not dull, heavy, or listless; lit.] light in head. (AA.)
yaqoZapN * : see what next follows.

yaqaZapN *
A state of waking, or being awake; (S, Mgh, K;) as also ↓ yaqoZapN, occurring in the saying of the Et-Tihámee,
AlEayo$u nawomN waAlomaniy~apu yaqoZapN
waAlomaro'u bayonahumaA xayaAlN saAriY
[Life is a state of sleep, and death is a state of waking; and man between the two is a night journeying phantom]; but most hold it to be used only by poetic license. (TA.)
yaqoZaAnu * : see yaqiZN, in two places. ― -b2- A^abuw AlyaqoZaAni The domestic cock. (K.)
maA raA^ayotu A^ayoqaZa minohu * (tropical:) [I have not seen any more vigilant, wary, or cautious, than he]. (TA.)
mutayaq~iZN * : see yaqiZN.

yalabN *
Shields, of the kind called tirosapN, (K,) pl. of turosN; or of the kind called daraqN, as is said in the R and M; which two kinds differ in this, that the drq, like the Hajaf, are of skin, or leather, without any wood or sinews (or nerves), whereas trs is a more general appellation: (TA:) or coats of defence, syn. duruwEN, (K,) of the fabric of El-Yemen: (TA:) made [app. whether shields or coats of defence] of skins; (K;) i. e., of the hides of camels: (TA:) or coats of defence (drwE) of the fabric of ElYemen, made of skins sewed together: a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is yalabapN: 'Amr Ibn Kulthoom says:
EalayonaA AlbayoDu waAlyalabu AlyamaAniY
waA^asoyaAfN yaqumona wayanoHaniynaA
[Upon us (were) helmets, and leathern coats of defence of the fabric of El-Yemen, and swords that are straight (so accord. to the above reading, of yaqumona, which I find in an excellent copy of the S: but some read yuqamona, which, I think, affords not so good a sense:) and that curve]: (S:) or helmets made of camel's hides: [see also A^alabN and A^alabapN:] or [head-coverings made of] plaited thongs of leather (nusuwEN) woven together, which are put on the head in lieu of the helmet: (TA:) or skins which are sewed together, and worn on the head, specially: (K:) or skins which are worn beneath the [kind of coat called] diroE, or [beneath that of] diybaAj; one of which is called yalabapN: or skins which are worn like the coats of defence called drwE: or skins of which such coats are made: (TA:) or any defensive coverings, or armour, of skins; not of iron; and hence, shields (daraqN) [of skins] are thus called: a poet says,
Ealayohimo kul~u saAbigapiK dilaASK
wafiY A^ayodihimi Alyalabu AlmudaAru
[Upon them (are, or were,) all (kinds of) ample coats of mail, smooth and glistening; and in
their hands, round shields of skins]: and yalabN, originally is a name of that skin [of which such coverings are made]: Aboo-Dahbal El-Jumahee says,
diroEiY dilaASN $ak~uhaA $ak~N Eajabo
wajawobuhaA AlqaAtiru mino sayori Aloyalabo
[My coat of mail is smooth and glistening: its cleaving (or sticking close) is an admirable cleaving: and its shield, of good dimensions, is of strips of skin: so accord. to explanations in the S, in arts. $k and qtr: but I incline to think that jwbhA here is the same as jayobuhaA; and that a word is understood, which makes the meaning to be its opening at the neck and bosom, of good dimensions, is bordered with an edge of thongs]: (S:) or simply skin, or hide. (K.) ― -b2- Also defensive coverings, or armour, of pieces of felt (lubuwd), with a stuffing of honey (Easal) and sand. (K.) ― -b3- Also, Steel; (K;) pure iron: (ISh, T, K:) n. un. yalabapN. (TA.) Of this signification, the following hemistich is cited as an ex.,
wamiHowarN A^axolaSu man m~aA'i Alyalaba
[And a pulley-axis clearer (in its brightness) than the lustre of pure iron, or steel]: but ISk says that it is by an Arab of the desert, who, hearing the verse of 'Amr Ibn-Kulthoom quoted above, erroneously supposed ylb to signify the most excellent kind of iron; and IDrd also asserts that the meaning assigned to it in this hemistich is founded upon a mistake. (TA.) See also A^alabapN. ― -b4- Also, Anything great, big, or large in size. (K.)

yanobuwtN *
A certain thorny kind of tree, not of the kind called EiDaAh. Mentioned here by IM. See art. nbt. (TA.)

yanobiyv *
A kind of sea-fish: (IAar, T:) different from the bayoniyv: it is doubtful whether it be Arabic, or a foreign word introduced into the Arabic language. (T.) [See arts. bnv and nbv.]
4 Ayht * (as also Awht, TA) It (flesh-meat, K, or a wound, TA) became stinking. (AZ, K.)

Alyahomuwtu *
A name of the fish upon which is the earth: erroneously written with b [Albhmwt]: so says Esh-Shiháb in the 'Imáyeh. (MF, TA.) [See my translation of the 1001 Nights, note to the Introduction.]

yuwHu * , (so accord. to AHat, Mbr, AAF, Kr, Abu-l-'Ala El-Ma'arree, A,) [of the fem. gender, (see buwHu,)] indecl., and without the art. Al (ISd,) accord. to IAmb buwHu, but this is a mistake originating from a corrupt transcription of the word, (IKh, IB, &c.,) and yuwHi, also indecl. like baraAHi, (TA) and yuwHaY, (IAth, K,) names of The sun. (S, art. bwH, K, &c.) [See buwHu.]
